support_summary: NPLOC4 (Nuclear protein localization protein 4 homolog) is a core cofactor of VCP, forming a stable complex with VCP and UFD1L that is crucial for recognizing and processing ubiquitinated substrates.

functions.cellular_process: NPLOC4 is an indispensable core component of the VCP-UFD1L-NPLOC4 complex. It functions synergistically with UFD1L to recognize and bind polyubiquitinated substrates destined for ER-associated degradation. NPLOC4 contributes to the high-affinity interaction with these substrates, ensuring their efficient delivery to the VCP ATPase for processing.
functions.effect_description: NPLOC4 acts as a substrate receptor for the VCP unfoldase, enabling the complex to process a diverse array of ubiquitinated proteins. Its collaboration with UFD1L is critical for the recruitment and subsequent unfolding of substrates by VCP.
biological_consequence: Assembly of the VCP-UFD1L-NPLOC4 complex → NPLOC4 and UFD1L cooperatively bind to polyubiquitin chains on ERAD substrates → The substrate is positioned at the central pore of the VCP hexamer → VCP's ATP-driven mechanical force unfolds and extracts the substrate from the ER membrane → The unfolded substrate is released into the cytosol for proteasomal degradation.
specific_effects: NPLOC4 and UFD1L cooperatively bind polyubiquitin chains, which is a prerequisite for substrate processing by VCP.
Mutations in VCP that cause multisystem proteinopathy can lead to tighter binding of the NPLOC4-UFD1L heterodimer and consequently, faster substrate processing.

evidence.paper_title: Ubiquitin- and ATP-dependent unfoldase activity of P97/VCP•NPLOC4•UFD1L is enhanced by a mutation that causes multisystem proteinopathy
evidence.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
evidence.relevant_quote: The best-characterized p97 adaptor is the heterodimer of NPLOC4/Npl4 and UFD1L/Ufd1 (UN), which recruits substrates in ERAD and other proteasome-dependent degradative processes.

evidence.paper_title: Multisystem Proteinopathy Mutations in VCP/p97 Increase NPLOC4·UFD1L Binding and Substrate Processing
evidence.relevant_quote: Here, we use biochemistry and cryoelectron microscopy to explore the effects of MSP mutations on the unfoldase activity of p97 in complex with its substrate adaptor NPLOC4⋅UFD1L (UN). We show that all seven analyzed MSP mutants unfold substrates faster. Mutant homo- and heterohexamers exhibit tighter UN binding and faster substrate processing.
